metadata.description: Singaporean seafood specialties, featuring fresh fish, prawns, crabs, and other marine delicacies

recipes.name: Hae Cho (Prawn Rolls)
recipes.description: A classic Teochew/Peranakan festive dish in Singapore, featuring minced prawn and pork seasoned with five spice, wrapped in beancurd skin and deep-fried until crisp. Served with sweet sauce and chili.
steps: Mix prawns, pork, water chestnuts, carrot, spring onion, egg, five spice, pepper, salt, sugar, and cornstarch in a bowl until well combined.
Wipe beancurd skin with a damp cloth and cut into rectangles. Place a portion of filling on each, roll up tightly, and seal edges with a little water or cornstarch paste.
Heat oil in a wok or deep pan. Fry rolls in batches over medium heat until golden brown and cooked through (about 5-7 minutes). Drain on paper towels.
Slice and serve with sweet sauce and chili sauce.
tips: Do not overcrowd the pan when frying for best crispiness.
Can be made ahead and reheated in an oven or air fryer.
Serve as part of a festive or celebratory meal.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Peranakan/Teochew home cooks.
recipes.origin: Teochew and Peranakan communities in Singapore; a festive and celebratory dish.

recipes.name: Fish Maw Soup (Yu Piu Tang)
recipes.description: A classic Chinese banquet and hawker soup in Singapore, featuring fish maw, crab meat, prawns, and mushrooms in a rich, savory broth. Served with black vinegar and white pepper, it's a festive favorite.

main.dried fish maw: 50g, soaked until soft and cut into pieces

steps: Soak fish maw in hot water until soft, then cut into bite-sized pieces.
Bring chicken stock to a boil with ginger. Add mushrooms, chicken, prawns, and fish maw. Simmer for 20 minutes.
Add crab meat and season with salt, pepper, and sesame oil.
Stir in cornstarch slurry to thicken. Slowly drizzle in beaten egg while stirring to create egg ribbons.
Serve hot, garnished with coriander and a dash of black vinegar.
tips: Use good quality fish maw for best texture.
Soup can be made ahead and reheated gently.
Add abalone or scallops for a more luxurious version.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
recipes.origin: Chinese community in Singapore; a festive and banquet favorite, also found at hawker soup stalls.

recipes.name: Singapore Chilli Crab
recipes.description: Iconic Singaporean dish of mud crab stir-fried in a sweet, spicy, and tangy tomato-chili sauce.
steps: Heat oil, fry onion, garlic, chilies, and ginger until fragrant.
Add crab pieces, stir-fry until shells turn red.
Add ketchup, chili sauce, sugar, soy sauce, and chicken stock. Simmer 10 minutes.
Add cornstarch slurry to thicken, then slowly stir in beaten eggs.
Garnish with spring onions and serve with mantou buns.
tips: Use live mud crab for best flavor.
Serve with fried mantou for dipping.
recipes.origin: Chilli Crab is Singapore's most famous seafood dish, created in the 1950s.

recipes.name: Black Pepper Crab
recipes.description: Mud crab stir-fried in a bold, peppery sauce with butter, garlic, and spring onions.
steps: Heat butter, fry garlic, onion, and black pepper until fragrant.
Add crab pieces, stir-fry until shells turn red.
Add sauces, sugar, and water. Simmer until sauce thickens and crab is cooked.
Garnish with spring onions and serve hot.
tips: Use live mud crab for best flavor.
Adjust pepper to taste.
recipes.origin: Black Pepper Crab is a Singaporean seafood classic, created in the 1950s.

recipes.name: Sambal Stingray
recipes.description: Grilled stingray slathered with spicy sambal, served on banana leaf.
steps: Blend sambal ingredients to a paste, fry in oil until fragrant.
Place stingray on banana leaf, spread sambal over.
Grill over medium heat for 15-20 minutes until cooked through.
Serve with lime wedges.
tips: Use fresh banana leaf for aroma.
Adjust chili for desired spiciness.
recipes.origin: Sambal Stingray (Ikan Bakar) is a hawker centre favorite in Singapore, known for its spicy sambal and smoky grilled flavor.

recipes.name: Cereal Prawns
recipes.description: Crispy prawns coated in buttery cereal crumbs, curry leaves, and chili padi.
steps: Coat prawns in cornstarch, deep-fry until golden and crispy. Drain.
Melt butter, fry curry leaves and chili padi until fragrant.
Add cereal and sugar, stir-fry until cereal is golden.
Toss prawns in cereal mixture and serve immediately.
tips: Use shell-on prawns for best texture.
Do not burn the cereal.
recipes.origin: Cereal Prawns is a modern zi char dish, popular at Singapore seafood restaurants.

recipes.name: Assam Fish
recipes.description: A spicy and sour fish curry made with tamarind, belacan, and a variety of fresh vegetables.
steps: Marinate fish with tamarind, belacan, garlic, onion, chilies, ginger, and fish sauce for 15 minutes.
Heat oil, fry garlic, onion, and chilies until fragrant.
Add belacan, tamarind, and sugar. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Add vegetables and fish. Simmer until fish is cooked and sauce thickens.
Season with salt and pepper.
tips: Use fresh tamarind for a more authentic flavor.
Adjust chili and spices to your liking.
recipes.origin: Assam Fish is a popular hawker dish in Singapore, combining spicy and sour flavors.

recipes.name: Steamed Teochew Fish
recipes.description: A delicate steamed fish dish with a fragrant sauce made from fermented bean curd, garlic, and ginger.
steps: Marinate fish with fermented bean curd, garlic, ginger, soy sauce, sugar, salt, and pepper for 10 minutes.
Steam fish for 15 minutes.
Serve with rice.
tips: Use fresh fish fillets for best texture.
Fermented bean curd adds a unique flavor.
recipes.origin: Steamed Teochew Fish is a traditional Teochew dish, known for its delicate flavors.

recipes.name: Salted Egg Yolk Prawns
recipes.description: Prawns coated in a rich, creamy salted egg yolk sauce, served with steamed rice.
steps: Beat salted egg yolks and mix with cornstarch until smooth.
Coat prawns in the sauce, ensuring each prawn is evenly coated.
Steam prawns for 10 minutes.
Serve with steamed rice.
tips: Use fresh salted egg yolks for the best flavor.
Adjust sauce consistency to your liking.
recipes.origin: Salted Egg Yolk Prawns is a popular dish in Singapore, combining the richness of salted egg yolk with the freshness of prawns.

recipes.name: Drunken Prawns
recipes.description: Prawns cooked in a sweet, spicy, and aromatic sauce, infused with rice wine and spices.
steps: Marinate prawns in rice wine, soy sauce, sugar, chilies, garlic, ginger, and pepper for 15 minutes.
Heat oil, fry garlic, ginger, and chilies until fragrant.
Add prawns and sauce. Simmer until sauce thickens and prawns are cooked.
Serve with steamed rice.
tips: Use fresh prawns for the best flavor.
Adjust rice wine and spices to your liking.
recipes.origin: Drunken Prawns is a popular dish in Singapore, combining sweet, spicy, and aromatic flavors.

recipes.name: Steamed Bamboo Clam with Garlic Vermicelli
recipes.description: Fresh bamboo clams steamed with garlic, vermicelli, and soy sauce. A seafood delicacy often found at zi char and seafood restaurants.
steps: Arrange soaked vermicelli on a plate, top with bamboo clams.
Mix garlic, soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, and oil. Spoon over clams.
Steam for 8-10 minutes until clams are just cooked.
Garnish with spring onions and chili. Serve hot.
tips: Do not overcook the clams or they will become tough.
Use fresh bamboo clams for best flavor.
recipes.origin: A popular seafood dish at Singapore zi char and seafood restaurants.

recipes.name: Steamed Cockles with Garlic and Chili Sauce
recipes.description: Fresh blood cockles (see hum) steamed and served with a spicy garlic-chili dipping sauce. A hawker and seafood favorite.
steps: Steam cockles for 3-5 minutes until shells open.
Mix garlic, chili, soy sauce, sugar, and oil to make dipping sauce.
Serve cockles hot with sauce and lime wedges.
tips: Do not overcook cockles or they will become rubbery.
Serve immediately for best texture.
recipes.origin: A classic Singaporean hawker and seafood dish, often enjoyed with beer.

recipes.name: Cantonese Steamed Fish
recipes.description: A classic Cantonese-style steamed whole fish with soy sauce, ginger, and spring onions. Delicate, aromatic, and a staple at Chinese banquets.
steps: Place fish on a heatproof plate, scatter ginger and spring onions on top.
Mix soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, sugar, and pepper. Pour over fish.
Steam for 12-15 minutes until fish is just cooked.
Heat oil until smoking, drizzle over fish to sizzle aromatics. Serve immediately.
tips: Use very fresh fish for best results.
Do not over-steam or fish will be dry.
recipes.origin: A staple at Chinese banquets and family dinners in Singapore.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: whole white fish (sea bass, snapper, or grouper)

recipes.name: Nyonya Steamed Fish
recipes.description: A Peranakan-style steamed fish with lemongrass, lime, chili, and aromatic herbs. Fragrant, tangy, and spicy.
steps: Stuff fish cavity with lemongrass, ginger, and some coriander.
Mix lime juice, soy sauce, sugar, salt, and oil. Pour over fish.
Scatter chili, garlic, and remaining coriander on top.
Steam for 12-15 minutes until fish is just cooked. Serve hot.
tips: Use fresh herbs for best aroma.
Do not over-steam or fish will be dry.
recipes.origin: A Peranakan favorite, blending Chinese and Malay flavors in a fragrant steamed fish dish.

recipes.name: Salted Egg Yolk Crab
recipes.description: A modern zi char and seafood favorite: crab stir-fried in a rich, creamy salted egg yolk sauce with curry leaves and chili. Iconic at Singapore seafood restaurants.
preparation: Coat crab pieces in cornstarch, deep-fry until just cooked. Drain and set aside.
Melt butter in a wok, fry garlic, curry leaves, and chili until fragrant. Add mashed egg yolks, stir until foamy.
Add evaporated milk, sugar, and salt. Toss in crab, coat well in sauce. Serve hot.
tips: Use fresh mud crab for best flavor.
Add more egg yolks for a richer sauce.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore seafood restaurants.
steps: Coat crab pieces in cornstarch, deep-fry until just cooked. Drain and set aside.
Melt butter in a wok, fry garlic, curry leaves, and chili until fragrant. Add mashed egg yolks, stir until foamy.
Add evaporated milk, sugar, and salt. Toss in crab, coat well in sauce. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Ikan Bakar (Grilled Spiced Fish)
recipes.description: A Malay and Indonesian favorite: whole fish marinated in a spicy sambal, grilled over charcoal or pan, often wrapped in banana leaves for extra aroma. Served with lime and sambal belacan.

fish.banana leaves: enough to wrap fish (optional, for aroma)

marinade/sambal.oil: 23 tbsp (for frying paste and brushing fish)

steps: Prepare Sambal: Blend shallots, garlic, chilies, lemongrass, and belacan into a paste. Fry paste in oil until fragrant. Add turmeric, tamarind, sugar, and salt. Cook until thickened. Cool slightly.
Marinate Fish: Rub fish with salt. Spread sambal generously on both sides and inside the cavity. Wrap fish in banana leaves (if using) and secure with toothpicks.
Grill: Grill fish over charcoal or on a grill pan, 810 minutes per side, until cooked through and slightly charred. (Alternatively, bake at 220C/425F for 2025 minutes.)
Serve: Unwrap and serve hot, garnished with lime and extra sambal belacan.
tips: Use banana leaves for authentic aroma and to keep fish moist.
Adjust chili quantity for desired heat.
Stingray, snapper, or seabass are traditional choices.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Ikan Bakar is a beloved dish at Malay stalls and seafood BBQs across Singapore and Malaysia.
